attributes.title: Has the Quality of Evidence for Medical Interventions Improved? Protocol for a Meta-Epidemiological Study
attributes.description: Protocol for a meta-epidemiological study examining whether Cochrane Reviews published in 2014 have been updated, and, if so, whether the GRADE quality of evidence has changed.

q1.value: Jeremy Howick, Despina Koletsi, Padhraig Fleming, Stefan Schmidt, Martin Loef, Harald walach, NIKOLAOS PANDIS, john Ioannidis

q2.value: We hypothesise that updating Cochrane Reviews results in a change in the quality of evidence compared with the original review, for a substantial number of the updated reviews.

q3.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Meta-epidemiological study of updated Cochrane Reviews from within an earlier sample (published 01/01/2013—30/06/2014).

We will search the Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews on 20 March 2020 to identify which of the reviews from the initial sample have been updated. Using the same methods to determine the quality of evidence in the 2016 analysis, we will measure the quality of evidence for the primary outcomes in the updated reviews. Furthermore, we will assess whether there was a change in the quality of evidence within specific Cochrane group domains.

q8.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

question.value: Two authors (DK and JH) will retrieve SRs for inclusion in the review by accessing the Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews, where information regarding updates are available. Data from the updated reviews will be extracted independently and entered on pre-piloted standardized forms after the initial calibration on 50 articles. Discrepancies will be resolved by discussion or, where necessary, with adjudication by a third researcher.
Change in GRADE evidence quality ranking.

Descriptive statistics will be presented for the surveyed sample. The quality of evidence according to GRADE will tabulated across intervention categories and Cochrane review groups. Univariable and multivariable logistic regression will be undertaken to assess the quality of the evidence according to GRADE (with outcome converted to binary: very low/low or moderate/high) relative to type of intervention, type of outcome (objective or subjective), and new SR or update. Model fit will be assessed using the Hosmer-Lemeshow goodness-of-fit test. Tabulations of statistical significance for each outcome and authors’ inter- pretations will be made for reviews with high and very low quality of evidence (according to GRADE), and comparison was made against the control group of reviews without GRADE assessments using Fisher’s exact test. All statistical analyses will conducted with STATA software (Stata Corporation, College Station, TX, USA).

q2.value: Henrik Serup Christensen, Åsa von Schoultz, Theodora Järvi, Mikko Mattila

q3.value:
This study sets out to explore candidate favourability among voters, focusing on the impact of recommendations and on risk taking. 
The literature on how voters decide, has long established that voters rely on information shortcuts to assist them in their electoral choice (Popkin 1991; Mondak 1993). Such shortcuts may increase voters’ cognitive efficiency, but also to reduce the time and effort devoted to deciding how to vote. Previous studies assert that the types of heuristics voters apply vary with the level of political sophistication of voters (Popkin & Dimock 1999). Less politically sophisticated voters are expected to be more responsive to simple cues, compared to voters with higher levels of political sophistication. 
Cues can come in different forms and be related to the political ideological schemata, or specific policy issues, but they can also be related to candidates various characteristics. The impact of recommendations from social networks or voting advice applications, and the extent to which voters are inclined to take risks when voting are however relatively unexplored aspects of candidate choice. We here test the effects of these in a conjoint experiment on candidate favourability fielded as part of a survey to a representative sample of the Finnish population.

q4.value:
H1: Recommendations have positive effects on candidate favourability.

H2: The effect of recommendations on candidate favourability vary according to the strength of the social ties to the source of the recommendation. 

H3: Recommendations have a stronger effects among people with less political sophistication.

H4: Uncertainty of winning a seat has a negative effect on candidate favourability 

H5: The effect of electoral uncertainty is weaker among respondents who are more prone to risk-taking

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
This is a choice-based conjoint survey experiment. The conjoint includes seven attributes with 3-5 levels: 
1. Gender of candidate (1. NO INFORMATION; 2. Male; 3. Female)
2. Age of candidate (1. NO INFORMATION; 2. 27; 3. 44; 4. 61)
3. The candidate’s educational background (1. NO INFORMATION; 2. Basic education; 3. Intermediate; 4. University degree)
4. The candidate’s political position (1. NO INFORMATION; 2. Close to own political views; 3. Far from own political views)
5. The candidate’s political experience (1. NO INFORMATION; 2. Holds office in local council; 3. Holds office in National parliament; 4. No current office holding)
6 Recommendation of candidate (1. NO INFORMATION; 2. Not recommended by anyone; 3. Voting Advice Applications; 4. Social media networks; 5. Family or close friends)
7. The probability that the candidate will win a seat (1. NO INFORMATION; 2. Very high; 3. Not high, not low; 4. Very low)

1000 respondents are shown seven comparisons of two candidates and each time they are asked to pick the one they would vote for.

q9.value: All respondents are randomly shown seven comparisons of candidates where the levels of each of the attributes are randomized.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: The respondents come from an online sample provided by Qualtrics. The sample will match the Finnish population when it comes to age, gender and place of living (Region, excluding Åland islands)

q13.value: The sample will consist of 1000 respondents, but since each makes seven comparisons of two candidates there will be 14000 units of analysis.

q14.value:
The recommendations for sample sizes when it comes to conjoint analyses are less straightforward than for conventional experiments, where power analyses can give a precise answer. A recommended minimum threshold for the number of respondents is (Orme, 2010, p. 64): (nta)/c=500
Where n is the number of respondents, t is the number comparisons made (here 7), a is the number of alternatives or profiles to choose from (here 2) and c is the largest number of levels for any attribute (here 15 since the analyses will include a 3x5 interaction). 

Accordingly, the minimum number of respondents is 536 people. Orme (2010: 65) emphasizes that this is a minimum requirement that should not be used to justify too small sample sizes). Another rule-of-thumb is that if you compare groups, there should be a minimum of 200 in each group. Since the inclusion of interaction effects between the recommendation attribute and political sophistication divides respondents into five groups, there should be at least 1000 respondents. Furthermore, it is also necessary to consider generalisability to the general population of interest (Aguinis & Bradley, 2014). However, there is also a wish to ensure a sample that is representative of the Finnish population when it comes to age, gender, and region. To ensure the representativeness the sample size will be 1000 individuals. While hardly a definitive number, this is sufficiently large to achieve credible and generalizable results without wasting resources or creating a risk for Type I errors or false positives.

question.value: The conjoint attribute levels are randomized to construct two candidate profiles and the respondents are asked to pick the one they would vote for in a national election.  Each respondent makes seven comparisons of profiles. No combinations are excluded meaning all combinations have an even chance of being shown.

The outcome variable is choice (yes/no), indicating whether the respondent picked a candidate in a given comparison.

Socio-demographics:
- Age: 18-70
- Gender: Male/ Female/Other/ Dont want to say
- Region and municipality of living
- Education

Political sophistication variables 
- Political interest: "Generally speaking, how interested are you in politics?" (Not at all interested – somewhat interested – not very interested  - Very interested)
- Internal efficacy: "To what extent do you agree or disagree with the following statements?" “Sometimes politics seems so complicated that I cannot quite understand what is going on” + “I consider myself well-qualified to participate in politics” (Totally disagree – Disagree – Neither disagree or agree - Agree- Totally agree)
- How often discuss politics: 5-point scale (never-almost every day)
- Party identification + what party identify with
- voting in 2019 national elections

General political attitudes
- Political trust: Trust in National parliament, political parties, government and politicians (each scored on a 0-10 scale with 10 highest level of trust)
- Left/right ideology: "In politics, people sometimes talk of 'left' and 'right'. Where would you place yourself on this scale, where 0 means the left and 10 means the right?" (0 “Left”; 10 “right”) 

Propensity for risk-taking: 
We use a battery of five items that asks individuals to judge their own willingness to take risks in different contexts to measure risk attitudes: ‘How willing are you to take risks… (1) in general, (2) in financial matters, (3) on the roads—when walking or cycling, (4) in sports and leisure activities, (5) that may affect your health. All items range from 0 to 10, where 0 means ‘Unwilling to take risks’ and 10 means ‘Fully prepared to take risks’.

The data is analyzed using linear regression with standard errors clustered at the individual level to take into account that each respondent makes five comparisons. The obtained coefficients indicate the Average Marginal Component Effect (AMCE), which is interpreted as the average change in the probability that a profile will win support when it includes the listed attribute value instead of the baseline attribute value. The NO INFORMATION attribute level will serve as baseline in all analyses.

The first part of the analyses involves to examine how the attributes affect evaluations of candidates, which involves a straightforward regression analysis where respondents’ choices are included as the dependent variable (coded profile chosen yes/no) and the attributes are included as categorical variables. All results are presented using coefficient plots, as recommended by Hainmueller et al. (2014).

The second step concerns differences in effects of recommendations depending on the level of respondents' political sophistication. Here the regression model includes interaction effects between sophistication variables (political interest, internal political efficacy, voting, party identification and discuss politics)  and the attributes to see whether their effects differ depending on the type of issue. This gives us the average component interaction effect (ACIE).  

For risk taking, the analyses will include interaction effects between respondents propensity for risk taking and the conjoint attributes. For this purpose, the variable for risk taking is recoded to a categorical variable (2 or 3 fold depending on distribution) dichotomy indicating whether respondents prefer risk taking or not.

q20.value:
Political sophistication variables and risk-taking index will be recoded into categorical variables whenever needed as part of the interaction analyses.

The exact grouping will depend on the distribution of respondents, but the aim will be to construct 2-3 groups that are meaningful and include a sufficient number of respondents.

q21.value:
We will rely on the standard  p<.05 criteria for determining that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct.

The reported results will also include confidence intervals in a coefficient plot.

Conditional marginal means will be reported together with AMCEs (possibly in an appendix)

q22.value: The analyses will aim to include all respondents who filled in the relevant questions.

q23.value: The respondents will be required to fill in all relevant questions meaning missing data should not be a problem. If problems occur, listwise deletion is used to handle missing data in the analyses.

q25.value: The survey is conducted in Finnish so all questions are translated from English to Finnish. It is envisioned that the results will be published in two separate papers, one focusing on the effect of recommendations and the other on the effects of risks.

attributes.title: Der Einfluss unterschiedlicher Bio-Kennzeichnungen von Milchprodukten auf die Konsumentenbewertung von Preis und Qualität.

q1.value: Der Einfluss unterschiedlicher Bio-Kennzeichnungen von Milchprodukten auf die Konsumentenbewertung von Preis und Qualität.

q2.value: Hannah Herrmann, Holly Herpichboehm, Julia Boettner

q3.value:
In den letzten 10 Jahren hat sich sowohl der Umsatz als auch der Marktanteil von Biolebensmitteln in etwa verdoppelt. Das Marktwachstum korrespondiert mit einer höheren
Kaufbereitschaft für Bioprodukte (Umweltbundesamt, 2016). Damit kommt der Vermarktung von Bioprodukten eine zunehmende Bedeutung zu, weshalb die Studie untersucht, wie
Konsumenten verschiedene Hinweisreize eines biologisch gekennzeichneten Produkts
hinsichtlich seiner Qualität und Bepreisung bewerten.

q4.value:
H 1a: Je mehr Hinweisreize eine Produktverpackung aufzeigt, desto höher fällt die
Zahlungsbereitschaft aus.
H 1b: Je mehr Hinweisreize eine Produktverpackung aufzeigt, desto höher fällt die
Qualitätseinschätzung aus.
H 2a: Von allen drei Hinweisreizen haben die Bio-Siegel den größten positiven Einfluss, die
Aufschrift “Bio” den zweitgrößten positiven Einfluss und das Landschaftsbild den geringsten
positiven Einfluss auf die Zahlungsbereitschaft.
H 2b: Von allen drei Hinweisreizen haben die Bio-Siegel den größten positiven Einfluss, die
Aufschrift “Bio” den zweitgrößten positiven Einfluss und das Landschaftsbild den geringsten
positiven Einfluss auf die Qualitätseinschätzung.
H 3a: Der Aufdruck der Bio-Siegel in Kombination mit der Aufschrift “Bio” hat den größten
positiven Einfluss, der Aufdruck eines Siegels in Kombination mit dem Landschaftsbild hat den
zweitgrößten positiven Einfluss und das Landschaftsbild in Kombination mit der Aufschrift “Bio”
den geringsten positiven Einfluss auf die Zahlungsbereitschaft.
H 3b: Der Aufdruck der Bio-Siegel in Kombination mit der Aufschrift “Bio” hat den größten
positiven Einfluss, der Aufdruck eines Siegels in Kombination mit dem Landschaftsbild hat den
zweitgrößten positiven Einfluss und das Landschaftsbild in Kombination mit der Aufschrift “Bio”
den geringsten positiven Einfluss auf die Qualitätseinschätzung.
H 4: Je größer das Wissen über das EU-Bio-Logo, desto größer ist der Einfluss der
Verpackungsgestaltung auf die Zahlungsbereitschaft und die Qualitätseinschätzung.
H 5: Je größer der Anspruch an Nachhaltigkeit, desto größer ist der Einfluss der
Produktverpackung auf die Zahlungsbereitschaft und die Qualitätseinschätzung.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Die Studie ist als within-subject 4x4 Design angelegt. Die Studie enthält Kontrollvariablen. Es
werden das Wissen zum EU-Bio-Logo sowie der Anspruch auf Nachhaltigkeit abgefragt, da
diese unter den Befragten unterschiedlich hoch ausgeprägt sein könnten.

q9.value: Es wird die Randomisierungs-Funktion des Online-Erhebungsportals SoSciSurvey verwendet.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q11.value: Es wurden bisher noch keine Daten gesammelt.

question.value: Der Fragebogen soll im Sinne eines Schnellballverfahrens online über soziale Netzwerke (z. B. Facebook, Instagram, WhatsApp) verbreitet werden. Dabei wird darauf geachtet, dass der Fra-gebogen breit gestreut wird, sodass verschiedene Altersgruppen und soziale Milieus angespro-chen werden. Die Erhebungsphase endet, wenn die gewünschte Teilnehmerzahl erreicht ist. Angestrebt ist ein Erhebungszeitraum von ca. vier Wochen.

q13.value: Es wurde eine a priori Poweranalyse mit dem Softwareprogramm „r“ durchgeführt. Mit einem Alpha-Niveau von .05 und der von Cohen (1992) vorgeschlagenen Power von .80 wird eine Stichprobengröße benötigt von n = 200, um die erwarteten kleinen (r = .2) Effekte zu finden.

question.value:
Alle acht Bilder der Milchprodukte wurden entsprechend der Hinweisreize manipuliert. 
Die Varianten dieser unabhängigen Variable sind: 
Milch:		Landschaft + Bio Siegel 
                        Landschaft+ Bio Siegel +  Aufschrift „Bio“
Joghurt: 	Aufschrift „Bio“
                        Bio Siegel + Aufschrift „Bio“
Quark: 	        Aufschrift „Bio“ + Landschaft
                        Landschaft
Butter: 		kein Hinweis
                        Bio Siegel

Zahlungsbereitschaft 

Die Zahlungsbereitschaft wird mittels des Price-Sensitivity-Meters (PSM) nach van Westendorp (1976) abgefragt. Dabei handelt es sich um eine direkte, ungestützte Preisabfrage zu Items wie „Welchen Preis empfinden Sie für das Produkt als günstig?“ und „Welchen Preis empfinden Sie für das Produkt als teuer, aber gerade noch akzeptabel?“..

Qualitätseinschätzung 

Die Qualitätseinschätzung wird mittels einer fünfstufigen Likert-Skala (1 = "stimme überhaupt nicht zu" und 5 = "stimme voll und ganz zu") zu folgenden fünf Aussagen erfasst:

„Das dargestellte Produkt stammt überwiegend aus ökologischem Anbau.“
„Das dargestellte Produkt enthält keine zusätzlichen Konservierungs- oder Farbstoffe.“
„Das dargestellte Produkt stammt von einer Kuh in artgerechter Haltungsform.“
„Das dargestellte Produkt stammt von einer Kuh, die gentechnisch nicht beeinflusst wurde.“
„Das dargestellte Produkt hat insgesamt eine sehr hohe Qualität.“


Wissen um Gütesiegel

Das Wissen zum EU-Bio-Logo wird mittels einer Wahr/Falsch Einschätzung entlang der zu-grundeliegenden Kriterien für das Logo erfasst. Beispielitems sind:

Mit dem EU-Bio-Logo gekennzeichnete Lebensmittel dürfen nicht durch und mit gentechnisch veränderten Organismen erzeugt werden.
Mit dem EU-Bio-Logo gekennzeichnete Lebensmittel dürfen nicht mehr als 15% konventionell erzeugte Bestandteile enthalten.
Das EU-BIO-Logo verbietet eine Tiertransporte von mehr als 6 Stunden.

Konsum und Einkauf 

Allgemeine Angaben zum Konsum und Einkauf von Milchprodukten werden angelehnt an Al-bersmeier, Mörlein & Spiller (2009) abgefragt. Die Befragten soll anhand einer fünfstufigen Li-kert-Skala (1= „Trifft ganz und gar nicht zu“ bis 5= „Trifft voll und ganz zu“) auf Items wie „Bei Milchprodukten gibt es große Qualitätsunterschiede“ oder „Für gute Milchprodukte zahle ich gerne etwas mehr“ antworten.

An dieser Stelle wird die Itembatterie ergänzt zu Items bezüglich dem individuellen Anspruch auf Nachhaltigkeit beim Einkauf. Nachhaltigkeit wird gemessen anhand der Items „Ich achte beim Einkauf auf eine nachhaltige Produktion“ und „Eine nachhaltige Konsumweise ist mir wichtig“.

Soziodemographie 

Es werden die grundlegenden demographische Daten zu Alter, Geschlecht, höchster Bildungs-abschluss, aktueller Beruf und monatliches Nettoeinkommen standardmäßig abgefragt.
Es werden jeweils Indizes gebildet aus den Items zu den Variablen Zahlungsbereitschaft, Quali-tätseinschätzung, Wissen, Konsum & Einkauf.

Als erstes werden die statistischen Deskriptiva der Variablen ermittelt. 
Die Hypothesen H1 – H3 werden mithilfe einer Mehrebenenregression überprüft.
Die Hypothesen H4 und H5 werden mithilfe einer Moderationsanaylse überprüft.

registration_responses.q1: Der Einfluss unterschiedlicher Bio-Kennzeichnungen von Milchprodukten auf die Konsumentenbewertung von Preis und Qualität.
registration_responses.q2: Hannah Herrmann, Holly Herpichboehm, Julia Boettner
registration_responses.q3:
In den letzten 10 Jahren hat sich sowohl der Umsatz als auch der Marktanteil von Biolebensmitteln in etwa verdoppelt. Das Marktwachstum korrespondiert mit einer höheren
Kaufbereitschaft für Bioprodukte (Umweltbundesamt, 2016). Damit kommt der Vermarktung von Bioprodukten eine zunehmende Bedeutung zu, weshalb die Studie untersucht, wie
Konsumenten verschiedene Hinweisreize eines biologisch gekennzeichneten Produkts
hinsichtlich seiner Qualität und Bepreisung bewerten.
registration_responses.q4:
H 1a: Je mehr Hinweisreize eine Produktverpackung aufzeigt, desto höher fällt die
Zahlungsbereitschaft aus.
H 1b: Je mehr Hinweisreize eine Produktverpackung aufzeigt, desto höher fällt die
Qualitätseinschätzung aus.
H 2a: Von allen drei Hinweisreizen haben die Bio-Siegel den größten positiven Einfluss, die
Aufschrift “Bio” den zweitgrößten positiven Einfluss und das Landschaftsbild den geringsten
positiven Einfluss auf die Zahlungsbereitschaft.
H 2b: Von allen drei Hinweisreizen haben die Bio-Siegel den größten positiven Einfluss, die
Aufschrift “Bio” den zweitgrößten positiven Einfluss und das Landschaftsbild den geringsten
positiven Einfluss auf die Qualitätseinschätzung.
H 3a: Der Aufdruck der Bio-Siegel in Kombination mit der Aufschrift “Bio” hat den größten
positiven Einfluss, der Aufdruck eines Siegels in Kombination mit dem Landschaftsbild hat den
zweitgrößten positiven Einfluss und das Landschaftsbild in Kombination mit der Aufschrift “Bio”
den geringsten positiven Einfluss auf die Zahlungsbereitschaft.
H 3b: Der Aufdruck der Bio-Siegel in Kombination mit der Aufschrift “Bio” hat den größten
positiven Einfluss, der Aufdruck eines Siegels in Kombination mit dem Landschaftsbild hat den
zweitgrößten positiven Einfluss und das Landschaftsbild in Kombination mit der Aufschrift “Bio”
den geringsten positiven Einfluss auf die Qualitätseinschätzung.
H 4: Je größer das Wissen über das EU-Bio-Logo, desto größer ist der Einfluss der
Verpackungsgestaltung auf die Zahlungsbereitschaft und die Qualitätseinschätzung.
H 5: Je größer der Anspruch an Nachhaltigkeit, desto größer ist der Einfluss der
Produktverpackung auf die Zahlungsbereitschaft und die Qualitätseinschätzung.

q6: No blinding is involved in this study.

registration_responses.q8.question:
Die Studie ist als within-subject 4x4 Design angelegt. Die Studie enthält Kontrollvariablen. Es
werden das Wissen zum EU-Bio-Logo sowie der Anspruch auf Nachhaltigkeit abgefragt, da
diese unter den Befragten unterschiedlich hoch ausgeprägt sein könnten.
registration_responses.q12.question: Der Fragebogen soll im Sinne eines Schnellballverfahrens online über soziale Netzwerke (z. B. Facebook, Instagram, WhatsApp) verbreitet werden. Dabei wird darauf geachtet, dass der Fra-gebogen breit gestreut wird, sodass verschiedene Altersgruppen und soziale Milieus angespro-chen werden. Die Erhebungsphase endet, wenn die gewünschte Teilnehmerzahl erreicht ist. Angestrebt ist ein Erhebungszeitraum von ca. vier Wochen.
registration_responses.q16.question:
Alle acht Bilder der Milchprodukte wurden entsprechend der Hinweisreize manipuliert. 
Die Varianten dieser unabhängigen Variable sind: 
Milch:		Landschaft + Bio Siegel 
                        Landschaft+ Bio Siegel +  Aufschrift „Bio“
Joghurt: 	Aufschrift „Bio“
                        Bio Siegel + Aufschrift „Bio“
Quark: 	        Aufschrift „Bio“ + Landschaft
                        Landschaft
Butter: 		kein Hinweis
                        Bio Siegel
registration_responses.q17.question:
Zahlungsbereitschaft 

Die Zahlungsbereitschaft wird mittels des Price-Sensitivity-Meters (PSM) nach van Westendorp (1976) abgefragt. Dabei handelt es sich um eine direkte, ungestützte Preisabfrage zu Items wie „Welchen Preis empfinden Sie für das Produkt als günstig?“ und „Welchen Preis empfinden Sie für das Produkt als teuer, aber gerade noch akzeptabel?“..

Qualitätseinschätzung 

Die Qualitätseinschätzung wird mittels einer fünfstufigen Likert-Skala (1 = "stimme überhaupt nicht zu" und 5 = "stimme voll und ganz zu") zu folgenden fünf Aussagen erfasst:

„Das dargestellte Produkt stammt überwiegend aus ökologischem Anbau.“
„Das dargestellte Produkt enthält keine zusätzlichen Konservierungs- oder Farbstoffe.“
„Das dargestellte Produkt stammt von einer Kuh in artgerechter Haltungsform.“
„Das dargestellte Produkt stammt von einer Kuh, die gentechnisch nicht beeinflusst wurde.“
„Das dargestellte Produkt hat insgesamt eine sehr hohe Qualität.“


Wissen um Gütesiegel

Das Wissen zum EU-Bio-Logo wird mittels einer Wahr/Falsch Einschätzung entlang der zu-grundeliegenden Kriterien für das Logo erfasst. Beispielitems sind:

Mit dem EU-Bio-Logo gekennzeichnete Lebensmittel dürfen nicht durch und mit gentechnisch veränderten Organismen erzeugt werden.
Mit dem EU-Bio-Logo gekennzeichnete Lebensmittel dürfen nicht mehr als 15% konventionell erzeugte Bestandteile enthalten.
Das EU-BIO-Logo verbietet eine Tiertransporte von mehr als 6 Stunden.

Konsum und Einkauf 

Allgemeine Angaben zum Konsum und Einkauf von Milchprodukten werden angelehnt an Al-bersmeier, Mörlein & Spiller (2009) abgefragt. Die Befragten soll anhand einer fünfstufigen Li-kert-Skala (1= „Trifft ganz und gar nicht zu“ bis 5= „Trifft voll und ganz zu“) auf Items wie „Bei Milchprodukten gibt es große Qualitätsunterschiede“ oder „Für gute Milchprodukte zahle ich gerne etwas mehr“ antworten.

An dieser Stelle wird die Itembatterie ergänzt zu Items bezüglich dem individuellen Anspruch auf Nachhaltigkeit beim Einkauf. Nachhaltigkeit wird gemessen anhand der Items „Ich achte beim Einkauf auf eine nachhaltige Produktion“ und „Eine nachhaltige Konsumweise ist mir wichtig“.

Soziodemographie 

Es werden die grundlegenden demographische Daten zu Alter, Geschlecht, höchster Bildungs-abschluss, aktueller Beruf und monatliches Nettoeinkommen standardmäßig abgefragt.

attributes.title: Governmental Response to Pandemics
attributes.description: This artefactual field experiment tests for messenger effects and framing feedback effects in the delivery of social-distancing guidance to the public.

q2.value:
H1: Pro-governmental ideology will be positively associated with pro-public health behavioral intent.
H2: Source expertise will be will be positively associated with pro-public health behavioral intent.
H3: Republican partisan identification will be positively associated with pro-economic behavioral intent; the partisan identification of message source will mediate this effect.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: An online survey will be conducted in March/April 2020, with one panel (N=1,500). CloudResearch, formerly TurkPrime, will be used to recruit respondents with a project title which stated “Answer a survey about your opinions on government responses to pandemics.” Unlike Amazon Mechanical Turk (Mturk), CloudResearch is an online platform designed specifically for scientific research which can post studies and instantaneously make them available to thousands of participants. Respondents will be assigned to one of 10 groups (2 x 5 factorial design) and presented with a hypothetical message from public officials related to COVID-19 and the need for social distancing. Respondents will then be presented with a choice of whether to go to a grocery store that for ingredients needed for that night’s dinner. Respondents will be based in the United States and screened to prevent repeat responses. Respondents will be paid $1.25 for completing the survey, and allotted 30 minutes to do so (average time for completion is expected to be approximately 10 minutes).

attributes.title: Does experiencing inattentional blindness reduce an eyewitness' credibility

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Does experiencing inattentional blindness reduce an eyewitness' credibility? This mock-juror study seeks to determine whether witnesses who experience inattentional blindness are perceived negatively in court.

other.value: Participants will also be asked some questions regarding their familiarity with the concept of IB. If sample size permits, we will analyse whether perceptions of witness credibility differ based on previous knowledge of the topic.

sample.value: As above, based on a power analysis, with a desired power of .90 and a medium effect size for a t-test (f = .50), at least 36 participants are needed. We will recruit up to 50 participants for the current study. When the valid number of participants reaches 50 (not including exclusions, see below), data collection will cease.

analyses.value:
1. Witness credibility: paired samples t-tests will be conducted to compare overall credibility ratings for each witness. Based on previous studies in our lab employing a similar methodology, we hypothesize that the witness who experienced IB will be perceived as less credible than the witness who saw the crime. 

2. Perceptions of defendant guilt. Frequencies of dichotomous verdicts will be reported. For perceptions of defendant guilt, 3 paired samples t-tests will compare perceptions of defendant guilt based on all the evidence presented, the evidence of the IB witness, and the evidence of the witness who saw the crime. Based on previous studies within our lab, we hypothesize that perceptions of defendant guilt will be significantly lower when based on the IB witness' testimony compared to the when based off all of the evidence, as well as solely based on the testimony of the witness who saw the crime. We also hypothesise that perceptions of defendant guilt will be significantly higher when based off the testimony of the witness who saw the crime, compared to when based off all the evidence presented. 

3. Attitudes towards inattentional blindness. Frequencies of responses to each of the above questions (yes, no, maybe) will be reported. We do not have specific hypotheses for these frequencies, but we do expect misconceptions to be present (i.e. participants stating that someone else would have seen the crime, that the IB witness should have seen the crime, and that the IB witness did actually see the crime).

outliers.value: Participants will be excluded if they fail to complete the entire study, or if they complete the study more than once. Additionally, attention check questions will be employed to exclude participants who fail to read and follow instructions. Finally, participants will be asked two questions regarding the content of each witnesses' testimony. Participants will be excluded if they fail to answer both questions correctly, as this would suggest they have confused the two witnesses together (or have not paid attention).

dependent.value:
Participants will read a trial transcript that contains two witnesses to an assault crime. One witness (Fields) experienced IB for the assault, as he was chasing after his dog that got off the leash, and therefore he did not see the assault occur. The other witness (Whittacker) noticed the assault as he was not completing an attention-demanding task. The witnesses were matched on all other factors.  

There are three dependent variables in this study:

1. Witness credibility. Based off previous studies conducted in our lab (see previous preregistrations), participants will rate how accurate, honest and credible they believed each of the two witnesses was. If responses for each witness on each of the three questions are highly consistent, these responses will be aggregated to form a single credibility score for each witness. This will be key measure of witness credibility, and we are interested in comparing the credibility ratings of the two witnesses, to see if the witness who experienced IB is perceived as less credible than the witness who saw the crime. 

2. Perceptions of defendant guilt. Participants will be asked to provide a dichotomous verdict of guilty/not guilty for the defendant, as well as to rate their belief that the defendant is guilty. They will complete three ratings of perceptions of defendant guilt: the first will be based on all the evidence presented, the second will be based on just the testimony of the IB witness, and the last will be based on just the testimony of the witness who saw the crime. These ratings will be compared using paired samples t-tests in order to determine whether the witness who experienced IB is reducing perceptions of defendant guilt. 

3. Attitudes towards inattentional blindness. Based on the questions asked in Jaeger, Levin, and Porter (2017), participants will be asked three additional questions specifically about the IB witness. They will be asked 1) whether someone else in Fields' (i.e. the IB witness) position would have seen the crime, 2) whether Fields (i.e. the IB witness) should have seen the crime, and 3) whether Fields (i.e. the IB witness) did actually see the crime. These questions serve to get an understanding of the misconceptions and attitudes participants hold towards IB.

conditions.value:
As the study is within-subjects, participants will all receive the same transcript, with the testimony of both the IB witness and the witness who saw the crime. 

Based on a power analysis, with a desired power of .90 and a medium effect size (f = .25), at least 36 participants are needed. We will recruit up to 50 participants for the current study. When the valid number of participants reaches 50 (not including exclusions, see below), data collection will cease.

hypothesis.value:
The current study will employ a within-subjects design using a mock-juror paradigm, to determine whether participants perceive a witness who has experienced inattentional blindness (IB) as less credible than a witness who has seen the crime (e.g. has not experienced IB). 

We are also interested in how witness inattentional blindness impacts upon perceptions of defendant guilt, and the attitudes participants hold towards a witness who has experienced inattentional blindness.

attributes.title: Improving Pretrial Court Appearance
attributes.description: Resource Development Associates (RDA) is collaborating with the San Francisco Pretrial Diversion Project (SFPDP) to conduct research on improving pretrial court appearance, with a focus on assessing the reasons why defendants with intensive needs fail to appear (FTA) in court. This study will use 20 years of data collected by the SFPDP to explore trends in FTA rates over time, the association of these trends with shifts in policy and practice, and the relationship between individual characteristics and FTA outcomes among individuals participating in the Supervised Release program.

q2.value: Cesangari Lopez-Martinez, Debbie Mayer, Stuart Buck, Kristin Bechtel, David Onek

q3.value:
Resource Development Associates (RDA) is collaborating with the San Francisco Pretrial Diversion Project (SFPDP) to conduct research on improving pretrial court appearance, with a focus on assessing the reasons why defendants with intensive needs fail to appear (FTA) in court. This study will use 20 years of data collected by the SFPDP to explore trends in FTA rates over time, the association of these trends with shifts in policy and practice, and the relationship between individual characteristics and FTA outcomes among individuals participating in the Supervised Release program. By utilizing a large population over a significant period, this study will inform potential enhancements in pretrial programming to improve FTA outcomes for individuals with intensive needs.

The study strives to inform the understanding of FTA outcomes by utilizing Supervised Release data to examine a population that poses a significant challenge with court attendance. The external validity of any potential finding will be limited to the characteristics of the program participants. As individuals with lower levels of risk and need are increasingly diverted from the justice system, resources are concentrated on individuals with higher levels of risk and need. By studying the factors associated with FTA for a generally high-needs population, this study seeks to gain insight into whether and how it is possible to support this population in maintaining compliance with court requirements.

Supervised Release is one of SFPDP’s most integral services, as it caters specifically to high-needs clients. Over more than 20 years of implementation, SFPDP has experienced variation in appearance and safety rates among Supervised Release participants, with current appearance and safety rates of 85% and 88% respectively.  Supervised Release case managers work with clients to determine their case management needs level, short- and long-term goals, and a corresponding treatment plan. In addition, Supervised Release case managers connect clients with short-term housing, outside treatment, and service providers who continue to work with clients after the conclusion of their cases. The goal of Supervised Release is to connect clients with the help they need to comply with court obligations including attendance at required court appearances. As such, this study will study a long-standing program that has experienced fluctuation in FTA rates over time and has witnessed significant shifts in legislative and judicial policy at the state level. In addition, SFPDP has implemented changes in practice, most notably the implementation of the Public Safety Assessment (PSA), developed by Arnold Ventures, which may have affected FTA outcomes for program participants.
Specifically, the study will focus on two primary research objectives: 
•	Objective A: Identify trends in Supervised Release participants’ FTA rates over time, how these trends change following significant shifts in policy and practice, and the association between participants’ characteristics (e.g., demographic characteristics, offense characteristics, prior criminal history, pretrial release court requirements) and FTA outcomes. 
•	Objective B: Quantitatively and qualitatively assess the association between FTA and individual, client stability, and court factors using a population of recent Supervised Release participants, to understand what factors are most strongly associated with FTA.
Given SFPDP’s leadership in pretrial best practices, research on Supervised Release participants has the potential to inform both programmatic and policy decisions for other jurisdictions seeking to implement effective pretrial practices. In addition, there are several unique aspects of the program that deem it worthy of further research, including its management by an independent nonprofit organization, its location in politically-dynamic California, and the high appearance and safety rate of its recent participants. While the program and population selected are unique compared to other pretrial release programs, the study is expected to yield important findings relevant to other jurisdictions.

q4.value:
This is an exploratory study with no a priori hypotheses. The objective is to find trends, changes over time, and associations between Supervised Release participants’ characteristics and FTA outcomes. The study will focus on three research questions:

Research Question 1: To what extent do individuals participating in the Supervised Release program fail to appear at scheduled court dates and how has this changed over time?
This research question establishes a starting point for the study by evaluating the extent to which individuals in the Supervised Release program fail to appear at required court hearings and presenting a portrait of the overall proportion of individuals that fail to appear. This component of the analysis is intended to provide context for the research by providing an overview of the population characteristics and the extent to which FTA occurred among this population over time. 

Research Question 2: To what extent do significant shifts in policy and practice align with changes in Supervised Release participants’ FTA rates over time?
Over the course of the study period, significant legislative actions and key judicial decisions have reshaped the criminal justice system and the social and economic support services available to individuals eligible for participation in the Supervised Release program, such as Assembly Bill 109, Proposition 47, and Proposition 57. In addition, there have been changes in the Supervised Release program itself that may be associated with individual outcomes. 

Research Question 3: To what extent are individual, client stability, and court factors associated with FTA outcomes among individuals participating in the Supervised Release program?
This question seeks to determine which factors are significantly associated with FTA outcomes, as well as the magnitude and direction of those relationships. The study will explore associations described in the sub-questions below.
o	Research Question 3.1: How are individual characteristics associated with FTA among individuals participating in the Supervised Release program?
o	The study will examine two types of individual factors: demographic characteristics and offense characteristics. By examining participants’ FTA outcomes by demographic characteristics such as age, race/ethnicity, and gender, the study seeks to identify whether some population groups have a higher probability of FTA than others. In addition to demographic characteristics, the study will also examine FTA outcomes by offense characteristics. Offense characteristics refers to the most serious offense at the time of charge. This analysis will examine both the offense level (misdemeanor/felony) and the offense type, including property, violent, drug, weapon, and public order offenses. Understanding differences in FTA outcomes by offense characteristics may provide insight into the extent to which certain offense characteristics are associated with a higher risk of FTA than others. 
o	Research Question 3.2: How are client stability characteristics associated with FTA among individuals participating in the Supervised Release program?
o	Both acute and chronic social and economic conditions, including factors such as homelessness, unstable housing, unemployment, and unstable employment, can pose significant challenges for individuals in their daily lives, making court appearances more challenging and potentially increasing the probability of FTA. In contrast, strong social support and stable housing conditions can act as protective factors for compliance with court requirements, including attendance. Research Question 3.2 is designed to understand how factors affecting participants’ social and economic stability may be associated with the probability that they will appear at required court appointments. This study will examine differences in individual stability characteristics to identify where the presence or absence of these factors is significantly associated with FTA outcomes. 
o	Research Question 3.3: How are court and case management requirements associated with FTA among individuals participating in the Supervised Release program? 
o	As a Supervised Release program participant, individuals are expected to remain in compliance with their assigned treatment plans, including attendance at court, calls and meetings with case managers, engagement in treatment services, and related requirements, which may include electronic monitoring. Research Question 3.3 examines the relationship between FTA outcomes and these court and case management requirements.

question.value:
The research team will conduct a descriptive study of longitudinal data from SFPDP’s Supervised Release Program. The study will utilize a mixed-methods approach to examine quantitative and qualitative data to understand trends in and factors associated with FTA among Supervised Release participants. Qualitative data will also add specificity and depth to the quantitative findings. While quantitative data analysis can identify which factors are most strongly associated with FTA, qualitative data is needed to answer the questions of why and how particular factors serve as barriers to appearing in court.
Specifically, this study will conduct:
1.	Descriptive analyses of Supervised Release participants’ FTA rates over time, including a descriptive analysis of trends in FTA before and after significant policy shifts and programmatic changes.
2.	Bivariate analyses of associations between FTA and factors related to Supervised Release participants’ history, stability, and court processes.
3.	Multivariate analysis to determine significance, strength, and direction of the relationship between factors identified in this study and participants’ FTA outcomes.
4.	Focus groups and interviews with participants, program staff and leadership, and stakeholders (e.g., District Attorney’s Office, Public Defender’s Office, Sheriff’s Office, judges).

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q11.value: All dependent and independent variables will be based on secondary, individual-level data for Supervised Release participants available through SFPDP databases. The source of individual-level data for the study will be database entries and case notes maintained by SFPDP for all participants. Prior to 2016, data were recorded in text-based electronic case notes that included specific fields related to enrollment date, court appearance date, and FTA status. Additional case data such as housing status and court requirements were also collected in electronic text fields. However, RDA cannot confirm the availability and quality of all data points for all participants. In 2016, following the implementation of the PSA, SFPDP implemented a new database management system that allowed staff to record detailed information about participant criminal history, current charges, terms of pretrial release, risk level, and individual needs. The research team has only had access to sample data for the population that will be included in the study. Sample data was provided for information purposes and the research team solely used the sample to review data availability, quality, and suitability for analysis (e.g., variability).

question.value:
RDA will access existing SFPDP administrative data and will not collect data for the quantitative analysis. The objective of the qualitative data collection is to provide depth to statistical findings and identify factors affecting FTA that may not be apparent in the quantitative data. Anticipated data collection participants will include:

Interviews (6-12)
•	SFPDP Leadership 
•	District Attorney’s Office staff
•	Public Defender’s Office staff
•	Sheriff’s Office staff
•	Judge(s) with eligible dockets 	

Focus Groups (6-12)
•	Supervised Release staff (2-4)
•	Supervised Release clients (4-8)

SFPDP will identify and contact potential client focus group participants. They will select a diverse group of Supervised Release participants based on main demographic characteristics (age, race/ethnicity, gender, and type of offense), risk of FTA (as identified by PSA risk measurement), and whether participants had a previous FTA. While it may be challenging to ensure the participation of individuals with an FTA in focus groups, SFPDP’s average daily caseload of 250 clients offers a sizeable pool of individuals who might be able to provide information to the research team. Recognizing the limitations of conducting focus groups with individuals with an FTA, RDA will also conduct telephone interviews with clients who are not able or willing to participate in a focus group and replace up to three of the client focus groups with up to 12 brief telephone interviews. Participation will be voluntary.
 
RDA will also conduct interviews with other stakeholders who work with potential or enrolled Supervised Release clients to learn about their experiences with this type of pretrial supervision, how they believe Supervised Release affects FTA outcomes, and what, if any, additional efforts are needed to improve FTA outcomes. Participants are expected to include representation from Superior Court judges, the District Attorney’s Office, the Public Defender’s Office, and the Sheriff’s Office. Participation in these components of qualitative data collection will be voluntary.

RDA will employ a framework analysis approach to interpret qualitative data. Data collected in interviews and focus groups will be compared across and within cases.  The objective of the client and staff focus groups and interviews is to understand what participants see as key contributors to FTA and what aspects of the Supervised Release Program serve as protective factors in preventing FTA. Focus groups and interviews are particularly useful because participants can respond to, indicate agreement with, and expand on each other’s comments.

q13.value: For the quantitative analysis, the population will include between 15,000 and 25,000 Supervised Release cases from 2000 through 2019. This range of data was chosen to provide the largest population possible for analysis with confidence in the available of data measures. We will focus the analysis of the association between individual characteristics and FTA rates on the population that participated in the program between 2016 and 2019, for which the full range of data is readily accessible. We expect to have information for 4,000-7,000 cases for this period.

question.value:
This study will explore:
•	Changes in Supervised Release participants’ FTA outcomes over time with a focus on differences before and after significant shifts in policy and practice (e.g. Assembly Bill 109, Proposition 47, Proposition 57, Implementation of the PSA, SFPDP change in timing of case planning). Based on data availability, FTA will be measured by (1) whether an individual missed any court appearance and/or (2) whether a bench warrant was issued in response to a missed court appearance.
•	The proportion of the Supervised Release participants that experienced an FTA and the proportion of the population starting Supervised Released each month that experienced a subsequent FTA. 
•	Individual factors that may be associated with FTA outcomes such as type of offense, FTA risk, and prior criminal history characteristics. 
•	Individual characteristics including age, race/ethnicity, gender, crime and offense type, PSA scores, prior misdemeanor and felony convictions, FTA history, housing and employment status, medical needs, and court requirements.

The study will conduct the following statistical analyses:
1.	Descriptive analyses of Supervised Release participants’ FTA rates over time, including a descriptive analysis of trends in FTA before and after significant policy shifts and programmatic changes (Research Questions 1 and 2).
Univariate analyses will be used to examine the proportion of the population that experienced an FTA and to graph changes in the proportion of individuals enrolled in SFPDP that experienced an FTA for that case. The research team will examine trends over time including before and after significant shifts in policy and practice. To more closely examine changes before and after such shifts, the research team will conduct chi-square tests to identify if there is a significant difference in FTA outcomes among Supervised Release participants before and after these shifts. If significant differences are identified, odds ratio calculation will be used to identify if there was a difference in the odds of FTA occurring before and after each date. Based on quantitative findings, the research team will discuss key findings with SFPDP staff and other stakeholders to provide context regarding how these changes may have influenced FTA outcomes among participants. This is not intended to imply causality, but to provide direction for further research to identify factors associated with changes in FTA rates over time.
2.	Bivariate analyses of associations between FTA and factors related to individuals’ history, stability, and court processes, among individuals participating in the Supervised Release program (Research Question 3).
The research team will examine a number of factors related to the individual, offense, prior history, client stability, and court obligations that may be associated with FTA outcomes. These characteristics are expected to be related to FTA outcomes based on existing literature and represent data that the research team has high confidence are available and of sufficient quality for analysis. The research team will conduct chi-square tests to identify if there is a significant relationship between each individual factor and FTA outcomes.
3.	Multivariate analysis to determine significance, strength, and direction of the relationship between factors identified in this study and participants’ FTA outcomes (Research Question 3).
The research team will use logistic regression to examine the significance, magnitude, and direction of the independent variables with FTA outcomes. First, a logistic regression will be conducted utilizing the dependent variable and all individual demographic characteristics as well as case and prior criminal history characteristics to identify the extent to which these characteristics are associated with FTA outcomes.  Next, measures of stability characteristics will be added to the model to examine their association with FTA outcomes and to identify the extent to which individual demographic and case factors are associated with FTA outcomes. This also allows the research team to identify the extent to which individual demographic and case factors are associated with FTA outcomes in the presence of client stability factors. Where the significant or magnitude of the relationship between demographic/case characteristics changes with the addition of client stability characteristics, this may indicate mediating or moderating effects, which the research team will explore to the extent possible. Finally, measures of case management will be added to the model to identify the extent to which these aspects of case management are associated with FTA outcomes. Again, this process may allow the research team to identify the extent to which individual demographic and case characteristics as well as client stability characteristics are associated with FTA outcomes in the presence of case management characteristics including potential interaction effects. To the extent possible, the research team will further investigate interaction effects where empirically justified. 

Qualitative Data

Qualitative data will be analyzed utilizing a framework analysis method to organize data by participant and code. RDA’s process will entail (1) familiarization with data, noting key context areas and identifying initial themes/categories; (2) establishment of codes to be applied across interviews and focus groups; (3) application of codes to data, including analysts convening to read and collaboratively summarize the data; (4) creation of tables of the data associated with the codes deemed most relevant; (5) interpretation and comparison of data to better understand the similarities and differences within and across each thematic category. Analysts will develop a matrix that includes rows (cases), columns (codes) and summarized data put into ‘cells.’ This outputted matrix helps to compare and contrast the data across the whole data while also ensuring that the individual’s holistic views are not lost. By using the matrix one can easily compare data within a single case and across cases in the analysis. RDA will use either Microsoft Excel or qualitative coding software ATLAS.ti to code data.

registration_responses.q2: Cesangari Lopez-Martinez, Debbie Mayer, Stuart Buck, Kristin Bechtel, David Onek
registration_responses.q3:
Resource Development Associates (RDA) is collaborating with the San Francisco Pretrial Diversion Project (SFPDP) to conduct research on improving pretrial court appearance, with a focus on assessing the reasons why defendants with intensive needs fail to appear (FTA) in court. This study will use 20 years of data collected by the SFPDP to explore trends in FTA rates over time, the association of these trends with shifts in policy and practice, and the relationship between individual characteristics and FTA outcomes among individuals participating in the Supervised Release program. By utilizing a large population over a significant period, this study will inform potential enhancements in pretrial programming to improve FTA outcomes for individuals with intensive needs.

The study strives to inform the understanding of FTA outcomes by utilizing Supervised Release data to examine a population that poses a significant challenge with court attendance. The external validity of any potential finding will be limited to the characteristics of the program participants. As individuals with lower levels of risk and need are increasingly diverted from the justice system, resources are concentrated on individuals with higher levels of risk and need. By studying the factors associated with FTA for a generally high-needs population, this study seeks to gain insight into whether and how it is possible to support this population in maintaining compliance with court requirements.

Supervised Release is one of SFPDP’s most integral services, as it caters specifically to high-needs clients. Over more than 20 years of implementation, SFPDP has experienced variation in appearance and safety rates among Supervised Release participants, with current appearance and safety rates of 85% and 88% respectively.  Supervised Release case managers work with clients to determine their case management needs level, short- and long-term goals, and a corresponding treatment plan. In addition, Supervised Release case managers connect clients with short-term housing, outside treatment, and service providers who continue to work with clients after the conclusion of their cases. The goal of Supervised Release is to connect clients with the help they need to comply with court obligations including attendance at required court appearances. As such, this study will study a long-standing program that has experienced fluctuation in FTA rates over time and has witnessed significant shifts in legislative and judicial policy at the state level. In addition, SFPDP has implemented changes in practice, most notably the implementation of the Public Safety Assessment (PSA), developed by Arnold Ventures, which may have affected FTA outcomes for program participants.
Specifically, the study will focus on two primary research objectives: 
•	Objective A: Identify trends in Supervised Release participants’ FTA rates over time, how these trends change following significant shifts in policy and practice, and the association between participants’ characteristics (e.g., demographic characteristics, offense characteristics, prior criminal history, pretrial release court requirements) and FTA outcomes. 
•	Objective B: Quantitatively and qualitatively assess the association between FTA and individual, client stability, and court factors using a population of recent Supervised Release participants, to understand what factors are most strongly associated with FTA.
Given SFPDP’s leadership in pretrial best practices, research on Supervised Release participants has the potential to inform both programmatic and policy decisions for other jurisdictions seeking to implement effective pretrial practices. In addition, there are several unique aspects of the program that deem it worthy of further research, including its management by an independent nonprofit organization, its location in politically-dynamic California, and the high appearance and safety rate of its recent participants. While the program and population selected are unique compared to other pretrial release programs, the study is expected to yield important findings relevant to other jurisdictions.

attributes.title: Alternative A and C motivations
attributes.description:
Participants will be asked to imagine their romantic partner engaging in relationship behaviors described in a series of vignettes, and asked for their responses to and causal interpretations of these behaviors. We will also measure participants' attachment styles, relationship satisfaction, and demographics information.

Rationale:
Avoidant and anxious attachment are described as the tendencies either to deactivate or hyperactivate the attachment system in response to threat. Avoidant attachment is therefore usually identified in both the research and popular psychology literatures as a habitual avoidance or fear of intimacy itself, and anxious attachment as a habitual approach towards or desire for intimacy itself. We propose that these descriptions inaccurately characterize the motivations driving avoidant and anxious attachment behaviors. 
	We propose, instead, and in keeping with the ontogenetic origins of avoidant and anxious attachment styles, two alternative goals and characterizations of avoidant and anxious attachment styles:

1.	The goal of avoidance is actually to maintain proximity by maintaining one’s ability to identify and fulfill one’s own needs and desires, without disrupting one’s relationships, and is adopted on the basis of a fear that one’s needs and desires are incompatible with one’s relationships and will lead to the discovery of relationship incompatibility and the dissolution of the relationship. This proposal is in keeping with the finding that avoidant attachment in infants is predicted by having attachment figures who move farther away rather than closer in response to their infants’ displays of distress and attempts to seek proximity. It is also theoretically consistent with the Dynamic Maturational Model’s characterization of avoidant attachment as based in compliance, with avoidance behavior being one component of the overarching strategy.
a.	(The goal of maintaining existing proximity is also consistent with conceptions of attachment to systems and the role of deactivation/palliation more broadly, e.g. system justification, just world beliefs, etc. and their effect on system-support at the sociopolitical level.)
2.	The goal of anxiety or preoccupation is actually to render the attachment relationship effective in its evolutionary and interpersonal function of protection from threat, and is adopted on the basis of a fear that despite having the relationship, the attachment figure will not fulfill one’s needs and desires. This proposal is in keeping with the finding that anxious attachment in infants is predicted by having attachment figures who are distracted and interfering or intrusive, but who respond to (i.e., whose caregiving can be regulated by) exaggerated proximity-seeking, or protest behaviors. It is also theoretically consistent with the Dynamic Maturational Model’s characterization of anxious attachment as based in coercion, with anxiety or preoccupation behavior being one component of the overarching strategy.

This alternative conceptualization of the motivations of avoidant and anxious attachment is also in keeping with Mikulincer and Shaver’s (2003, p.23) observation that “dismissing individuals possess available representations of self during security-enhancing interactions with an attachment figure and can use them in threat contexts,” whereas preoccupied individuals do not possess these available representations. As Schafer (1968, p.9) describes, “internalization refers to all those processes by which the subject transforms real or imagined regulatory interactions with his environment, and real or imagined characteristics of his environment, into inner regulation and characteristics.” Whether real or imagined, avoidant individuals seem to have positive if idealized representations of experiences with attachment figures, whereas anxious individuals seem to lack even realistic (flawed, non-idealized) representations of satisfying experiences with attachment figures, leading the former to seek to protect and maintain potential access to these experiences, and the latter to seek to render their relationships more satisfying of their needs and desires.

Rationale In Brief:
•	NOT
o	Avoidant attachment: Fear of and avoidance of intimacy
o	Anxious attachment: Desire for and preoccupation with intimacy
•	BUT RATHER
o	Avoidant attachment: Concern with retaining relationship
o	Anxious attachment: Concern with receiving sufficient caregiving

attributes.title: Corticosteroid in the Treatment of Hand Osteoarthritis: A Systematic Review and Meta-analysis of Randomized Controlled Trials

q1.value: Corticosteroid in the Treatment of Hand Osteoarthritis: A Systematic Review and Meta-analysis of Randomized Controlled Trials

q4.value: Treatment with the glucocorticoid  in patients with painful hand osteoarthritis is associated with  pain relief

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Patients: adults with hand osteoarthritis, regardless of its subset (including thumb-base osteoarthritis, interphalangeal osteoarthritis，carpometacarpal osteoarthritis, intermetacarpal osteoarthritis, metacarpophalangeal osteoarthritis, erosive osteoarthritis)
Intervention and control: any form of intra-articular corticosteroids or oral corticosteroids in the hand joints vs. placebo, non-pharmacological treatment, or different doses, frequency or duration of the same therapy.
Outcomes: The primary efficacy outcome was pain on a visual analogue scale (VAS) or a numerical rating scale (NRS). Secondary efficacy outcomes were self-reported physical function, patient global assessment, joint activity, health-related quality of life and hand strength. The safety outcomes that were assessed included the number of withdrawals due to adverse events, the number of (local or systemic) adverse events and the number of serious adverse events.
Study design: RCTs.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

question.value: Two reviewers independently extracted data from the included trials using a standardized extraction form. In case of incomplete or unextractable data, we contacted authors. Disagreements were resolved by consensus or determined by a third independent reviewer.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 500 participants.

question.value: The primary efficacy outcome was pain on a visual analogue scale (VAS) or a numerical rating scale (NRS). Secondary efficacy outcomes were self-reported physical function, patient global assessment, joint activity, health-related quality of life and hand strength. The safety outcomes that were assessed included the number of withdrawals due to adverse events, the number of (local or systemic) adverse events and the number of serious adverse events.

Meta-analysis was performed using a random-effects model to estimate pooled relative risk (RR) and 95% confidence intervals (CIs). Heterogeneity was assessed using the I2 test, values greater than 50% indicating substantial heterogeneity. Potential publication bias was evaluated by the funnel plot.
